results.title: Spectacular disasters
results.brief_description: Over the decades, images of mass destruction, whether natural or human, have been captured on film and television. This video presents a compilation of some of that footage beginning with natural disasters including the 1906 San Francisco earthquake and fire, the 1913 floods in Ohio, the collapse of the Takoma Bridge in 1940 and some of the major hurricanes that have hit America over the years. It then follows on to human created disasters such as the many failed attempts at flying the skies via planes, rockets, helicopters and airships, with some amazing shots of the Hindenburg exploding. Also includes footage of the Titanic, the sinking of the Lusitania, and the dropping of the atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. There are some light-hearted moments but there are also some disturbing visions (and commentary) contained in this documentary compilation. Presented by George Takei. In English with Spanish subtitles.

results.title: Spectacular canyons
results.creator_credit: Reinald Werrenrath Jr and Journal Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Natural Phenomena Series”.
Uses diagrams and spectacular photography to introduce the geomorphological agents involved in the creation of canyons. Covers rivers, valleys and glacial valleys showing the processes of weathering and erosion. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Spectacular Britain
results.creator_credit: Richard Brock and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: David Attenborough takes the viewer the length of Britain in one year. Some of its most beautiful countryside is shown as well as some fascinating wildlife. The gardens of Buckingham Palace are filmed for the first time.
results.description: David Attenborough takes the viewer the length of Britain in one year. Some of its most beautiful countryside is shown as well as some fascinating wildlife. The gardens of Buckingham Palace are filmed for the first time.

results.title: Spectacle: Interview with Curators Jonathan Wells and Meg Grey Wells
results.creator_credit: Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
“How many exhibitions would have the range of Bob Dylan to Kanye West?” (Jonathan Wells)
Flux Curators Jonathan Wells and Meg Grey Wells share what inspired ‘Spectacle: The Music Video Exhibition’, the challenges in bringing over 300 clips into an exhibition context and their favourite areas in the exhibition.
Created as part of ‘Spectacle: The Music Video Exhibition’ 26 September 2013 - 23 February 2014.

results.title: Spectacle Talks: Hello Flux Panel Discussion
results.creator_credit: Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
A special panel discussion held at ACMI on 26th September 2013. Exhibition curators Jonathan Wells and Meg Grey Wells joined an extended panel that included Alexei Tylevich (the designer of ‘Spectacle: The Music Video Exhibition’) and Australian music video directors Darcy Prendergast, Josh Thomas, Luci Schroder and Kris Moyes.
Moderated by ACMI curator Amita Kirpalani, the panel discusses the exhibition, personal experiences in production and the art of the music video. Filmed as part of ‘Spectacle: The Music Video Exhibition’ 26 September 2013 - 23 February 2014.

results.title: Spectacle Talks: Gotye and his Collaborators
results.creator_credit: Gotye, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Multi award-winning musician, songwriter and producer Gotye is no stranger to collaboration. His music videos are a testament to this, utilising the talents of diverse directors, artists and animators. Often involving a range of complex animation and filmmaking techniques, visual worlds are created floating seamlessly against his music.
Natasha Pincus, Andrew Goldsmith, and directors of Rubber House animation studio Ivan Dixon and Greg Sharp disscus a selection of Gotye’s most renowned videos. These include ‘Easy Way Out’, ‘Seven Hours With A Back Seat Driver’, ‘State Of The Art’ and the international chart-topping ‘Somebody That I Used To Know’.
Hosted by film and music critic Megan Spencer, this event provided a fascinating insight into the collaborative journey, from initial concept and creative development, through to final clip production.

results.title: Spectacle Director Showcase: Oh Yeah Wow
results.creator_credit: Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
‘Oh Yeah Wow’ are a Melbourne based creative collective that make music videos, short films and TV programs. In this interview directors Darcy Prendergast, Seamus Spilsbury and Josh Thomas discuss music videos.

Created as part of “Spectacle : The Music Video Exhibition” 26 September 2013 - 23 February 2014. ACMI Digital Programs worked with Exhibitions to interview five Australian directors featured in the exhibition about the art and techniques of music video production.

results.title: Spectacle Director Showcase: Natasha Pincus
results.creator_credit: Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Natasha Pincus is a multi award winning Australian music video director and producer and has won the ARIA award for Best Music Video two years in a row. Her stop motion animation video for Gotye’s ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ has had a staggering 420 million views. Natasha talks about getting her first big break making a music video for Paul Kelly.

Created as part of “Spectacle : The Music Video Exhibition” 26 September 2013 - 23 February 2014. ACMI Digital Programs worked with Exhibitions to interview five Australian directors featured in the exhibition about the art and techniques of music video production.

results.title: Spectacle Director Showcase: Leo Baker
results.creator_credit: Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: Celebrated animator Leo Baker discusses working with Australian band ‘Children Collide’ to create a hybrid live-action and animation video for their song ‘Praying for Sunshine’. Aside from making music videos, Baker was also one of the lead animators on the Oscar-winning screen adaptation of Shaun Tan’s acclaimed ‘The Lost Thing’.

Aside from making music videos, Baker was also one of the lead animators on the Oscar-winning screen adaptation of Shaun Tan’s acclaimed ‘The Lost Thing’.

results.title: Spectacle

constellations_primary.name: Spectacle
constellations_primary.description: The moving image has captured some of history’s biggest moments. From newsreel shorts in cinemas before the show to the arrival of TV, nightly news and the 24-hour news cycle to social media, news has become a spectacle.

constellations_primary.name: Rodney King LA Riots
constellations_primary.description: The brutal beating of Rodney King by the LAPD was caught on amateur videotape and became what is arguably the first video of police brutality to go viral before the internet. It was a catalyst for the 1992 LA riots, which has influenced media ever since.

constellations_primary.name: Hell no, we won't go
constellations_primary.description: The cultural, social, psychological and political effects of the Vietnam War have been explored through cinematic classics, musicals and comedies.

results.description: The moving image has captured some of history’s biggest moments. In the early 20th century, Australians received much of their information from newsreel shorts in cinemas before the main feature. This shared viewing experience represented the way film, and the media, could turn current events into spectacles, and these shorts were an important predecessor to the nightly news that followed when television arrived in the 1950s. As the century progressed, world events were broadcast directly into homes, helping accelerate social, political and cultural change. Today, technological advancements also fuel new formats, like the 24-hour news cycle and social media, which blur the lines between information and entertainment while reflecting the hope, tragedy and joy of human experience.
description_for_label: The moving image has captured some of history’s biggest moments. In the early 20th century, Australians received much of their information from newsreel shorts in cinemas before the main feature. This shared viewing experience represented the way film, and the media, could turn current events into spectacles, and these shorts were an important predecessor to the nightly news that followed when television arrived in the 1950s. As the century progressed, world events were broadcast directly into homes, helping accelerate social, political and cultural change. Today, technological advancements also fuel new formats, like the 24-hour news cycle and social media, which blur the lines between information and entertainment while reflecting the hope, tragedy and joy of human experience.
